image.altText: A swarovski bag full of cash and coupons, a pair of Air Jordans, a watch, a bottle of perfume and an apple.

items.synopsis: An ABC examination of the gifts handed to teachers in the past 18 months has found their receipt apparently breaches the enforceable regulation under the Queensland Public Sector Act.

title.children: Queensland teachers have been gifted robot vacuums, Air Jordans and concert tickets. Some are asking if it's too much

image.altText: An elderly lady holds up two faded photos of a small, smiling boy.

items.synopsis: It's been almost 50 years since Jimmy Taylor vanished from outside a shop in his home town. Now a new suspect and a $1 million reward have sparked hopes the mystery may be solved.

title.children: Jimmy Taylor was 12 when he vanished. Now there's a new suspect and a $1 million reward

image.altText: Antarctica hits new low sea ice extent

items.synopsis: Antarctica's sea ice is now reforming as the continent moves deeper into the austral winter, but it's currently the smallest it has ever been for this time of year on record. This blip in the Antarctic pulse is the latest in a string of record lows that is being watched carefully by scientists.

title.children: A stutter in Earth's icy heartbeat has 'gravely concerned' scientists searching for answers

image.altText: A man with grey hair and bushy grey beard stands in front a wall that says Indigenous Knowledge Centre.

items.synopsis: Like many in his community, Douglas Graham wants to see the Queensland town of Woorabinda — and the lives of the people in it — improve, but he is unsure if or how the Indigenous Voice to Parliament would help.

title.children: In the Indigenous community of Woorabinda, Douglas is one of many unsure about a Voice to Parliament

image.altText: Family photo of woman, man and child smiling happily

items.synopsis: Two years after signing a $430,000 fixed price contract, boilermaker David Niblitt can no longer afford to finish the home that he and his wife had hoped they'd be living in by now.

title.children: David's half-built house is an 'absolute nightmare' and might send him bankrupt

image.altText: A woman with a black blazer holders a book while standing in a garden.

items.synopsis: South Korea hoped that a 69-hour working week would encourage more women to have children and solve the country's ageing population problem, but women say the real barrier is embedded in the culture.

title.children: South Korea wants women to have more babies, but their latest idea outraged millennials and Gen Z

image.altText: Former Hawthorn senior management Chris Fagan, Alastair Clarkson and Jason Burt.

items.synopsis: An independent panel investigating allegations of racism at the Hawthorn Football Club concludes, making no findings against former senior coaches and managers.

title.children: AFL shuts down Hawthorn racism review as First Nations players seek to 'resolve all differences'

image.altText: a group of male students wearing backpacks walk through a uni campus away from the camera. their faces can't be seen

items.synopsis: For the past decade, student debts have increased by about 2 per cent a year on average, but tomorrow they will rise by a massive 7.1 per cent. The consequences of increased debt will affect graduates for decades.

title.children: Indexation of student debts to have lifelong impacts on Australians' borrowing capacity

image.altText: Littleproud looks off camera, bordered by two silhouetted figures.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Nationals leader defends consultants, and police search for gunmen after Florida shooting. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Federal Opposition will back an increase to the JobSeeker unemployment benefit of $40 a fortnight. The policy was announced by Treasurer Jim Chalmers in his second budget earlier this month, and equates to an extra $2.85 per day. The Coalition wants to increase the income threshold for people on JobSeeker to earn money before their benefits are cut, from $150 to $300 a fortnight. The Opposition will attempt to amend the government's legislation to tack that idea on to the plan — but it's unlikely to succeed, and the Coalition will back the broader increase to the rate instead.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Opposition to back government's JobSeeker increase

props.alt: A bald man in glasses and a suit stands in front of an Australian flag

children.content: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton.
(ABC News: Dave Sciasci)
The Federal Opposition
will back an increase to the JobSeeker unemployment benefit of $40 a fortnight
The policy was announced by Treasurer Jim Chalmers in his second budget earlier this month, and equates to an extra $2.85 per day.
The Coalition wants to increase the income threshold
for people on JobSeeker to earn money before their benefits are cut, from $150 to $300 a fortnight.

The Opposition will attempt to amend the government's legislation to tack that idea on to the plan — but it's unlikely to succeed, and the Coalition will back the broader increase to the rate instead.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: South Korea's military says North Korea has launched what it had called a space satellite, toward the country's south. The launch has prompted emergency alerts and evacuation warnings in parts of South Korea and Japan. Air raid sirens have been heard across the South Korean capital of Seoul as the city issued a warning asking citizens to prepare for potential evacuation. The Japanese government issued an emergency warning over its J-Alert broadcasting system for residents of the southern prefecture of Okinawa, saying a missile has been launched from North Korea. North Korea had said it would launch its first military reconnaissance satellite between May 31 and June 11 to boost monitoring of US activities.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Emergency warnings in South Korea and Japan as North Korea launches satellite

props.alt: Overhead aerial satellite photo of a rocket launchpad near roads and trees

children.content: Satellite picture by Planet Labs PBC shows activity at a launch pad near Tongchang-ri, North Korea.
(AP: Planet Labs PBC)
South Korea's military says
North Korea has launched what it had called a space satellite
, toward the country's south.
The launch has prompted
emergency alerts and evacuation warnings
in parts of South Korea and Japan.
Air raid sirens have been heard across the South Korean capital of Seoul as the city issued a warning asking citizens to prepare for potential evacuation.
The Japanese government issued an emergency warning over its J-Alert broadcasting system for residents of the southern prefecture of Okinawa, saying a missile has been launched from North Korea.
North Korea had said it would launch its first military reconnaissance satellite between May 31 and June 11 to boost monitoring of US activities.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Nationals leader David Littleproud has defended the former government's prior use of external consultants, in the wake of the PwC tax leak scandal. The consultancy firm, which was also employed by the former government, is under fire for the leaking of confidential Australian government information related to tax changes for large multinational corporations, which it shared with some of its clients. Here's what Littleproud said when asked on News Breakfast if he or members of the former government accepted any responsibility for the ballooning use of consultants, and the capping of public servant numbers: "I think it's about balance, it's about a place for these consultants. What you can do is move with agility to be able to get a more cost effective way to bring in skills that the department doesn't have on a temporary basis. "That means that you can get the advice, take the advice, where that couldn't be sort from the departmentmental people that you had. "With respect, I think it's the actions of PwC subsequent to that. I think this is about where, in balancing budgets, you need to understand you're using Australian taxpayers' money and you have to do that efficiently and if you're able to be able to do that by bringing people in on a temporary basis to get the skill sets you don't have in the department and don't need full-time, that's common sense. "But it's about making sure it's done in balance and done to the right extent, and then the actions of PwC show there should be actions taken against them for what they've done. "I think it also demonstrates we should go further and beyond this unholy alliance. It's not just our sides. It's both sides have had, with the big four accounting firms. "We need to think more laterally. Not all the wisdom of the world sits within the big four. Some of the smaller firms out there also have many people that could bring those skills to the Australian bureaucracy on the temporary basis that brings in greater competition and diversity of ideas that the departments and ministers are looking for."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Nationals leader defends former government's use of consultants, in wake of PwC scandal

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
Nationals leader David Littleproud has defended the former government's prior use of external consultants, in the wake of the PwC tax leak scandal.
The consultancy firm, which was also employed by the former government, is under fire for
the leaking of confidential Australian government information related to tax changes for large multinational corporations
, which it shared with some of its clients.

Here's what Littleproud said when asked on News Breakfast if he or members of the former government accepted any responsibility for the ballooning use of consultants, and the capping of public servant numbers:

"I think it's about balance, it's about a place for these consultants. What you can do is move with agility to be able to get a more cost effective way to bring in skills that the department doesn't have on a temporary basis.
"That means that you can get the advice, take the advice, where that couldn't be sort from the departmentmental people that you had.

"With respect, I think it's the actions of PwC subsequent to that. I think this is about where, in balancing budgets, you need to understand you're using Australian taxpayers' money and you have to do that efficiently and if you're able to be able to do that by bringing people in on a temporary basis to get the skill sets you don't have in the department and don't need full-time, that's common sense.
"But it's about making sure it's done in balance and done to the right extent, and then the actions of PwC show there should be actions taken against them for what they've done.
"I think it also demonstrates we should go further and beyond this unholy alliance. It's not just our sides. It's both sides have had, with the big four accounting firms.

"We need to think more laterally. Not all the wisdom of the world sits within the big four. Some of the smaller firms out there also have many people that could bring those skills to the Australian bureaucracy on the temporary basis that brings in greater competition and diversity of ideas that the departments and ministers are looking for."

image.altText: Ice on a path with trees

items.synopsis: More than 100 Australian weather stations have just registered their coldest May minimum temperatures on record. And the cold snap had Sydney experiencing some of its iciest May nights in 66 years.

title.children: Australia shivers through one of its coldest Mays

image.altText: A composite of three images

items.synopsis: With almost half of Australians having a parent born overseas, multicultural Australians' vote in the Voice referendum could prove significant. It's a cohort both the Yes and No campaigns are trying to court with community forums.

title.children: 'We can no longer be ignored': Why the Yes and No campaigns are courting multicultural votes ahead of the Voice referendum

image.altText: Linda Matthews holds a photo of her and her late husband

items.synopsis: When Brad Liefvoort died of a drug overdose, his wife didn't know he had been prescribed with thousands of highly addictive tablets from several GPs. His death has sparked a regulatory overhaul.

title.children: Brad was prescribed 'masses' of highly addictive drugs. His widow is demanding to know why

image.altText: A man and woman sit a bench, looking at paper bills, with a calculator and laptop next to them

items.synopsis: Economists are divided on how well households will weather the storm of rent rises, soaring home loan rates and rising prices, just as Australians are divided in how much financial pressure they're under.

title.children: 'I don't think that's sustainable for the economy': How the RBA might drag Australia into recession

image.altText: A worker abseils against a building to inspect drone damage.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin says the biggest-ever drone strike on Moscow targeted civilians, accusing Ukraine of an attack that would warrant a "severe" response.

title.children: Russia warns Ukraine of harsh response after 'terrorist' drone strike on Moscow

image.altText: A Chinese fighter jet is seen through the window of a plane.

items.synopsis: Video shows a fighter jet passing in front of the US plane's nose and the cockpit of the RC-135 shaking in the turbulence.

title.children: Chinese jet carried out 'aggressive' manoeuvre near US military plane, Washington says

image.altText: Graphic showing the merging of a human head and electronic circuits

items.synopsis: Top artificial intelligence executives join experts and professors in raising the "risk of extinction from AI", urging politicians to equate it with risks posed by pandemics and nuclear war.

title.children: Tech world warns risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority

image.altText: milk on shelves in the supermarket

items.synopsis: After surviving drought, floods and the dollar-a-litre years, dairy farmers say they have been blindsided by a drop in farm gate prices just when things were finally looking up.

title.children: Milk price drop a 'slap across the head' for dairy farmers

image.altText: A woman holds an adrenaline pen and anti-inflammatory tablets in a garden.

items.synopsis: One sting from a jack jumper ant lurking in Jennie Kun's garden could be deadly. She's just started a treatment program to train her body to stop being allergic, but says it needs to be made more accessible.

title.children: Jennie loves gardening but she has to 'suit up' to protect herself against a deadly ant

image.altText: Sohae Satellite Launching Station is seen in a satellite image.

items.synopsis: South Korea's military says North Korea has launched a space-launch vehicle after announcing a plan to put its first military spy satellite into orbit.

title.children: North Korea launches  satellite; warnings lifted in South Korea and Japan

image.altText: A drone shot of about 20 tents on Yarralin oval.

items.synopsis: The population of flood-affected Pigeon Hole remains in limbo, living out of temporary accommodation on a school oval where a pop-up school, food hall and recreational activities are the centre of everyday life.

title.children: Months after flood evacuations, this NT community is living in tents far from home

image.altText: A street photograph of protesters carrying signs demanding an end to the Franklin dam plans.

items.synopsis: Activists involved in the protest that saved the Franklin River say the environmental win would not have been possible under today's anti-protest laws.

title.children: Their fight made history, but these environmental activists say their tactics wouldn't work today

image.altText: A drone shot of large wind turbines with a clear blue sky in the background

items.synopsis: Outback Queensland is home to the largest potential wind zone in the country, but a lack of infrastructure and a shortage of skilled workers are major roadblocks in reaching national renewable energy targets.

title.children: 'Daunting shortage' of skilled workers looms over giant, renewable energy projects

image.altText: Old wooden boat is half emersed in water, still on its mooring at Empire Bay.

items.synopsis: One of Sydney's first steam tugboats has come to a watery end on the NSW Central Coast, just months before she was due to undergo extensive restoration work.

title.children: Restoration of beloved Sydney heritage tugboat scuppered after boat sinks

image.altText: The plane which was carrying the four children was discovered in thick jungle.

items.synopsis: The discovery of a rudimentary shelter, some half-eaten fruit and a fresh footprint leads authorities to say they are "very close" to finding the children, who they believe have roamed the jungle since a plane crash.

title.children: Rescuers 'very close' to finding lost kids after finding footprint in Colombian Amazon

image.altText: A man in a dark navy suit and pink tie speaks in parliament, with an Indigenous female minister sitting behind, watching on

items.synopsis: The new Australian Centre for Evaluation will be tasked with examining whether government programs work — before they are rolled out. Imagine how much good it could do if it's allowed to, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Will Albanese live up to his own promises to end pork-barrelling? There is a sliver of hope

image.altText: Kosovo tensions

items.synopsis: NATO will deploy more forces to northern Kosovo after 30 of its peacekeepers were injured in clashes with ethnic Serb protesters.

title.children: NATO to send 700 more troops to Kosovo to help quell violent protests

image.altText: Close up of blonde haired woman in dressed in black.

items.synopsis: The 39-year-old startup founder could spend more than 11 years inside a prison camp in Texas for defrauding investors in a hoax that became a parable about greed and hubris in Silicon Valley.

title.children: Elizabeth Holmes begins 11-year sentence for Theranos blood-testing hoax

image.altText: A stern man in a suit walks outside court as a video photographer follows him

items.synopsis: Chris Dawson's former student has given evidence against the 74-year-old convicted murderer, who is facing one count of carnal knowledge, in the NSW District Court.

title.children: Chris Dawson treated student like his 'property' and 'groomed' her, court told

image.altText: Chris Jordan stares intently while answering a question at Senate Estimates. His brow is furrowed.

items.synopsis: The Australian Taxation Office raised concerns about a confidentiality breach at PwC to Australian Federal Police in March 2018, but a lack of detail meant no investigation was launched.

title.children: Lack of detail stopped federal police initially investigating PwC breach

image.altText: Artist impression of a pterosaur flying over a beach

items.synopsis: Fossils dated to 107 million years old have been confirmed as the oldest evidence in Australia of the prehistoric flying reptile that some liken to the mythical dragon.

title.children: Fossils of prehistoric flying reptile found on Victorian coast are the oldest remains ever uncovered in Australia
